direction.raw_text: . PACIFIC OCEAN -- DAY                                        2 A lone palm tree rises up into a yellow afternoon sky.  Behind it, the sparkling blue of the Pacific Ocean and the city of San Diego.  A dry, hot Southern California day.  Even the wind is lazy, and a little bored.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NEIGHBORHOOD SHOPPING CENTER - DAY                                3 Santa Claus wears shorts and sandals, ringing a bell as he collects for the Salvation Army.  This is Christmas in the Southland.  No snow, no winter wonderland.  Just a pleasantly thick heat and an unchanging season, as music continues. Turning the corner, walking into frame is ELAINE MILLER, 35. She is a tall woman, consumed by the fevered conversation she's Having with her pale young son WILLIAM, late pre-teens.  They stand apart from the other shoppers.  All around them is the highly-charged salesmanship of the season... silver glittering fake Christmas trees.  She hurries her son through the commercial juggernaut, continuing their lively intellectual conversation, when something stops her.  A Workman is affixing letters to a store-front.  He has already placed the MERRY... now he's finishing the XMAS.  Elaine is strong, but always pleasant, always clear about her purpose in this life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Workman nods thanks, with faux appreciation, as Mom turns away.  The Workman shares a look with William, who shrugs - that's my Mom.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, I'm a teacher.  There is no word in The English Language -- "Xmas." It's either Merry Christmas... or Happy Holidays.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : 1969 4        EXT.  MINI-TRACT CONDO COMPLEX -- DAY                                4 This is the new professional-class.  It's a mini-condo community.  Rows of Spanish-styled three-bedroom houses with common walls.   Move in on one of these homes, the one without Christmas lights.  At the door is a furtive 15 year-old Girl. She checks her cheek, straightens her hair.  She hides something under her coat, and gathers the proper nonchalance to enter.  Music fades.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . KITCHEN -- DAY                                                5 We now hear the dialogue between this lively Mother and her son, as she cooks a pan full of soy-based health-food cutlets. The meal simmers unappetizingly in the pan.  Across the kitchen we see William.  He's a great listener, with a calm and curious face that takes everything in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William nods, intrigued.  He has a good disposition.  The world of knowledge engages him, and he loves what it brings out in his Mom.  There is a small clatter at the front door, as the girl we've just seen enters, barely brushing some chimes. She silently curses herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mom moves to the living room to greet William's sister.  William peers into the next room.

direction.raw_text: .   SCHOOL DANCE/GYMNASIUM BATHROOM -- NIGHT                        7 Music continues.  Shot moves along a row of very mature-looking male teenagers, examining themselves in the bathroom mirror. There's the kid with a very mature-looking moustache, the  kid proudly sporting full-blown hormonal acne (he slaps on some Hai Karate ), the guy to whom puberty has already delivered the face of an adult, complete with long jutting sideburns... and then a blank space at the mirror, as the shot moves down, down, down to find William.  He is so much younger, without a zit in sight.  Puberty is so very distant on his horizon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DANCE -- NIGHT -- UNDER-CRANKED                                 8 Song continues as we see William's perspective of these much- older looking kids.  Girls now are visible, and they are even more mature than the boys we've just seen.  They flirt and glow, arms trailing across the shoulders of the boys. Whispering in each other's ears, none of them looking down. It's a troubling experience, to be this close to the alluring world of older teenagers... and to be so invisible to them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Are you really in our grade?

result.heading: JUNIOR HIGH LOCKER ROOM -- DAY 9 VOICE

direction.raw_text: . JUNIOR HIGH LOCKER ROOM -- DAY                                  9 VOICE (louder) Are you really in our grade? William turns to see tall, adenoidal TIM TOBIN.  The most mature looking kid we've seen yet, he challenges William in a loud theatrical tone.  It is a voice right out of Guys and Dolls, which incidentally is the school play in which Tobin had just starred.  William answers in a respectful voice.  He is desperate for acceptance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Others now begin to gather around, examining William.  He has never been more naked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Their voices echo off the tiled walls.  Now everyone is watching the hairless William.  He is confused by their meanness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All eyes are on him, waiting for a response.  The kid's mental wheels turn frantically.  And from somewhere comes an attitude, a swagger, and somehow the perfect line arrives from what could only be a merciful deity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is a new persona for the kid -- the witty guy.  And it works. Guy #2 cracks up, then others.  William's new accuser is suddenly surrounded by the impressed gales of laughter of these older boys.  Others turn away, on to other things.  Tobin stares at William, and then also turns away.
direction.name: direction

Anita's good-looking boyfriend DARRYL, a dead ringer for young Stephen Stills, loads her suitcases into a large turqouise Chevy.  The suitcases are adorned with plastic stick-on flowers.    All coolness is leaving William's life.  Mom watches nearby, worried and helpless.   (Their house is more austere, less "fun" than the other front lawns.)

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anita turns and heads towards them.  She focuses on William, placing her hands on his young shoulders.  Her face is very close to him now, as she delivers this sage prediction of the future.

direction.raw_text: . DARRYL'S CAR - DAY                                                14 Anita looks back at the receding American Gothic-image of her mother and brother.  Sister waves to brother.  She feels for him.  Music now shifts to The Who's "Sparks."

direction.raw_text: . BEDROOOM -- NIGHT                                                15 William locks the door.  He reaches under his bed.  It's a black leatherette travel bag, with tartan design.  He unzips the bag -- it's filled with albums.  He flips through the amazing, subversive cache of music.  Cream's Wheels of Fire... the seminal Bob Dylan bootleg Great White Wonder... the Rolling Stones' Get Yer Ya Ya's Out... The Beach Boys' Pet Sounds... Abraxas by Santana... Jethro Tull's Stand Up... The Mother's of Invention's We're Only In It For The Money...  Led Zeppelin... Crosby, Stills and Nash... Miles Davis' Bitches Brew... and The Who's Tommy... with a note taped to it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The heady effect of all these albums registers, as we see him lighting a candle.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) "Listen to Tommy with a candle burning and you will see your entire future..."
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: :  1973 DETAIL SHOT OF NOTEBOOK A blue school notebook, with ballpoint pen renderings of the names of groups like the Who and Led Zeppelin, complete with carefully drawn thunderbolts.  Also, the name LESTER BANGS.

direction.raw_text: . JOURNALISM CLASS -- DAY                                        16 William, now 15, sits in class with book, Adventures in Journalism. His hair is shoulder-length.  A dedicated teacher,
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FOOD MACHINES - DAY                                                17 William presses the food machine button, pulls an orange from a vending container.  He still looks younger than most of the students... and these days, especially the girls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LUNCH COURT -- DAY                                                18 William sits apart from all the others, under a tree.  He reads intently, happily, as he eats the orange.  It's a copy of Creem Magazine.  Music continues.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Camera moves across the photos, catching the expressions and fashions of the rock heroes of the day.  Ian Anderson of Jethro Tull, eyes wide and hair flying as he plays flute.  Neil Young, enigmatic with perfectly patched Levis.  The Southern Rock Royalty of The Allman Brothers Band, posing and laughing in front of massive stacks of amps.  Marc Bolan of T. Rex, his ringlet-hair backlit by stage lights.  David Bowie in skin-tight Japanese one- piece attire, onstage with The Spiders From Mars.  Pete Townsend of the Who, slashing windmill-style at his guitar. Drift down to a by-line - by Lester Bangs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PARKING LOT - DAY                                                19 William walks through the parking lot after school.  Everybody now congregates around the new arrival of their lives - their own cars.  Arms suddenly clap William on the back, friendly faces smile strangely, laughing.  He takes a few steps and looks up to see... a school official is hurriedly removing something from the high-school marquee.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: WILLIAM MILLER IS TOO YOUNG TO DRIVE, (OR FUCK)

direction.raw_text: which reads: WILLIAM MILLER IS TOO YOUNG TO DRIVE (OR FUCK) All are laughing.  He laughs with them, and turns as his face goes slack.  He shrugs, marches on.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: DOWNTOWN SAN DIEGO RADIO STATION -- DAY 20

direction.raw_text: . DOWNTOWN SAN DIEGO RADIO STATION -- DAY                        20 The song we've been listening to is ripped off the turntable by a highly-active man in a red promotional t-shirt proclaiming the greatness of The Guess Who.  He is a ferocious, lumbering, music- driven presence, and he fills this small radio studio to the very brim.  This is LESTER BANGS, 25, the rarely-seen God of a then new art-form -- Rock Journalism.  A Disc-jockey with long- long hair watches helplessly.  William views all this through a glass window.  He stands on the corner of a downtown side street, halfway up a steep incline.  He is the only person on the streets this early Saturday morning.  Reveal that he is watching a live radio show, audible to us through the small p.a. speaker overhead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bangs searches for the album -- vinyl flying everywhere now, with no regard for album jackets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . RADIO STATION -- DAY                                                21 William watches intently.  Bangs thuds the needle onto a copy of Raw Power. We're rewarded with a blast of Iggy and the Stooges' "Search and Destroy."   A closer shot on William now watching the whirlwind of anarchy inside.  Lester does an Iggy Pop impression, acting out a story for the d.j. that we cannot hear, never noticing the kid soaking in everything from the other side of this double-glass window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . RADIO STATION -- DAY -- LATER                                22 Bangs walks with William on this sharply inclined San Diego street.  It's early, the streets are silent.  Bangs is about fifteen beer pounds overweight.  His jeans are loose, his paleness and messy moustache an emblem of the long days and nights spent writing.  In there somewhere is a good-looking guy.  His hands are thrust deeply into his pockets, and he takes big sweeping steps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The kid nods, they walk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bangs looks at the much smaller kid, shaking his head.  It's too late for newcomers.  But if the kid's age is an issue, he doesn't mention it.  Like a machine-gun:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For a moment, the serious demeanor dissolves and the oddest thing happens.  Bangs laughs.  It's an odd and charming laugh, the kind a tough guy keeps well-hidden.  It surprised the kid, who smiles back.  Bangs stops at the corner, and offers a pleasant but very final nod of the head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . OUTER RADIO STATION - NIGHT                                        62 Humble Pie.  "Thirty Days in the Hole."  Russell and band enter the radio station, passing through the now-empty front office. As always, Russell sets the tone.  He's feeling good. Stillwater takes over -- they feel mighty, like the Beetles, as they climb across chairs, rearrange wall hangings and gold records  and head down the small hallway to the control room interview.  Rolling with the flow are William and Penny in her green coat.  He tries to distance himself from her -- still a little stung by the earlier hallway rebuff -- but she will have none of it.  She privately shares every great passing moment with him.  He tries not to succumb to these charms. It's hard.  Music segues to Stillwater's own "Fever Dog."

direction.raw_text: . RADIO CONTROL ROOM - NIGHT                                        63 Stillwater's own record spins, and it sounds good to everyone in this room.  Russell takes a seat near the open mike.  Jeff Bebe is quick to take the other seat, arranging himself to be just as close to the microphone as Russell.  William watches all as he sits at the dark back of this control booth. Stillwater sits with late-night progressive disc-jockey QUINCE ALLEN, 25. Quince takes a long hit from a joint and does not pass it. The entire Stillwater band is now collected in the studio and ready for the interview.   William can't avoid looking at Penny Lane, who looks great tonight.  She catches him, and he barely looks away in time.  Polexia, newly reconciled with Jeff, notices.  The very mellow disc-jockey eases up to the microphone, as the finale of "Fever Dog" is just ending.

Jeff Bebe sits in a chair nearby.  Dick laughs at a joke. Always the life of the party, Penny Lane dispenses stolen towels from a maid cart.  And she is the first to slip into the pool for some after-hours, against-the-rules swimming.  Effortlessly, she turns a collection of people into a party. In his important voice:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lights come up, as the band launches into "Fever Dog."   Jeff begins singing.  Russell reaches to adjust the microphone for a back-up vocal and is hit with something unexpected. A sharp electrical shock. It's just a slight pop in the loud din of music, but within a moment something is clearly wrong.  Russell holds onto the microphone stand with a surprised look, conducting high-voltage for two seconds and then he snaps his hand off the metal.  His face is white, he takes off his guitar and walks off-stage, collapsing a couple steps later.

She blows out the candles, vamping Marilyn Monroe-style, and sucks off the frosting seductively, to cheers. Russell watches, as we push in on Penny. dialogue.raw_text: Be honest and unmerciful. (beat) You're doing great.  Call me later is you want.  I'm always up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . ROLLING STONE OUTER OFFICE -- MORNING                        154 Ben Fong-Torres and David Felton look at William's new manuscript with great interest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William sleeps restlessly nearby, mouth agape, sitting upright in a plastic chair.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Read me the opening line.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reads aloud)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: am flying high over Tupelo, Mississippi, with America's hottest band, and we are all about to die."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mmmmm. (as if sampling wine) Dark. Lively.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, and it gets better. (impressed) Did this all really happen?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (jealously reaches for manuscript) Give it to me.  I'll call and check the quotes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NEW TOUR BUS -- DAY                                                 155 The band rides in a new tour bus.  The palpable tone in the air is -- PANIC.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All eyes look to Russell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Russell nods.  He looks at Silent Ed, drumming soundlessly on a rubber pad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ed silently nods thanks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dennis hands Russell the phone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Look.  Let's just piece together our information...  because the fact-checker asked us all about different parts of the story.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did he write about?  What's he using?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It. All. He's using it all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So what? (beat) We come off like amateurs... some average band...  trying to come to grips, jealous and fighting and breaking up - we're buffoons!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe we just don't see ourselves the way we really are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was supposed to be our friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (ruefully, remembering) I told him to write what he wanted.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Russell) By the way, he has you on acid, screaming "I Am A Golden God" from a fan's rooftop.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (immediately remembering) Oh my God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They used him to fuck us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (still back at "Golden God") I didn't say "Golden God."  Or did I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We never took him seriously, and now it's serious.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I liked him as a person.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was never a "person!"  He was a journalist!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You.  You had the right idea all along.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nervously) How about the plane flight?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's all in there.  But don't worry, it's all unspecific who say what.  No names are mentioned in the more embarrassing sequences, it's just completely obvious who's who!  We're fucked!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I forgot he was there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, they haven't talked to Russell - he can always deny the key stuff to the fact checker.  Then they can't print it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (brightening) Is that true?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's war, my friend.  If you'd met me earlier, he would have never been on the around.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) He'll live.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . ROLLING STONE OFFICES -- DAY                                        156 William is still being congratulated by his new peers.  We see him woozy but beaming, as Allison the Fact Checker comes out of her office, waving the manuscript.  She works her way through the cluster of editors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone looks at William, who is speechless and confused. Their congratulations stop on a dime.  The fact checker can't resist twisting the knife a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The kid has been sandbagged.  The machine of a big-time magazine whirs into action on another story, as the cluster moves down the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William sits there, as only David Felton stay behind, brandishing his cigarette-holder.  He sits down next to the kid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at the kid, decides to offer a personal parable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The kid looks at him, too tired and still in shock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He exits.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The band just denied 90% of the story. It's a fabrication.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) You weren't honest.  And worse, you wasted our time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you talk to Russell?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Russell Hammond is the one who denied it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (darkly) Crazy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (one last shot, to William) We're going with the Who - !
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's just some fan... what did you expect?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I believe you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) Jim Morrison once came to my house and drank a beer.  The beer is still on my mantle.  I'm 35 years old with Jim Morrison's beer as a shrine.  I wanted to be Earnest Hemingway.  Instead.  I have Jim Morrison's beer. (shrugs, he's learned to live with it) If you didn't make your story up, good for you.  If you did make it up... good for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) Say something, so I know you're alive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodbye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Powerful  word.  Strong.  Final.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BACKSTAGE CREW MEAL - NIGHT                                        157 Russell Hammond sits down on a plastic chair with a paper-plate filled with buffet-style food - steak and baked potato. Preoccupied, and several seats away from other crew members. He drinks a glass of milk.   Out old friend Sapphire takes the seat next to him, holding a skimpy paper plate of vegetables.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They eat in silence.  Sapphire looks around.  The new breed of groupies eye her, as they cruise Russell on the periphery. They're bolder, flashier.  She eyes them back with seniority.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The girls still circle Russell nearby.  He's unaware.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks sadly at her plate of vegetables.  An ever-sharp mind in last night's clothes, she commands Russell's respect.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Russell nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Russell stares into his crew meal, nodding a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Russell smiles to himself, knows it's true.  Dick passes, placing hands on Russell's shoulders, massaging a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dick claps Russell on the back, and moves on.  He turns to Sapphire.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I feel bad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, at least you feel.  That puts you in a higher class of asshole.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did I do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well - you can do what the big boys do. (he looks at her) Nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You believe these new girls?  None of 'em take birth control, and they eat all the steak.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) They don't even know what it id to be a fan!  To blindly love some silly piece of music... or some band so much that it hurts... please,  they're all just after the money.  Shoo -- (in their direction) Go rob a bank!  It's more honest!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is Penny okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Quaalude Incident.  Yeah, it wasn't pretty.  She could have died.  I always warned her about letting too many guys fall in love with her.  I guess I was wrong. (shrugs) On of 'em saved her life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, it's finally over with Leslie. I'm going to call her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let her retire. (he doesn't respond) You want to lock her up in a house in Michigan? Please. (he doesn't respond) Write her a song someday.  She deserves it.  Something about that girl brought out the best in a lot of... (looks around backstage) ... pretty average people.  She deserves it...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) (forward thinking) ... because something tells me twenty years from now, we'll remember her... and not much else.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have a good vacation.  I hope the band stays together.  Before it all went down the shitter, it was starting to get really good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not going to blame myself.  I do make people happy.  They just shouldn't get to know me... 'cause it appears to spoil everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be so easy on yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What gives you the right to get this personal with me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's not reminisce.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . SAN FRANCISCO AIRPORT -- NIGHT                                158 William moves like a zombie through the airport, and collapses in a seat.  He sits still in the crowded flow of human traffic. A cluster of Flight Attendants pass.  One stops, a stylish young woman wearing a tall bubble-shaped PSA hat with swirling colors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at her.  He feels like he's on Mars, and she looks like a Martian.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William looks woefully at them, like a dog who's been hit by a car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anita looks in her brother's face.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: William?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) You guys this is my brother!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (ad if meeting a celebrity) "The Narc?! "
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You guys, I'll deadhead back later.  I think I'm needed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nice to finally meet you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have a good day!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You look awful, but that's great. You're living your life! You're finally free of... her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey.  I'll take off work.  Let's have an adventure together.  You and me, finally.  Anywhere you want to go. Anywhere in the world.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . WILLIAM'S HOME -- DAY                                        159 William whistles the family whistle.  Sister and brother trudge up the steps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William whistles again.  Mom meets them at the door.  She looks at her trashed son who has finally come home.  For the first time, she hugs Anita first, and it's not lost on Anita. It's a clumsy neck-hug, neither wanting to commit.  The kid passes to his Mother's left, with suitcase, intentionally nudging her into his sister.  Anita takes this as an aggressive act of love, and hugs her mother back.  Tears stream down Mom's face.  Their cheeks touch. Mom pulls away, and sees her own tears on Anita's face.  Thinking that she's also crying, she grabs a tissue for them both.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This is not my idea of a good time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just get me to my bed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (resigned) I'll deal with her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . ELAINE'S HOUSE -- CONTINUOUS                                        160 The kid stands in the hallway listening, shaking his head, poised to enter his room, unseen by them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now they really hug, Anita gulping back real tears.  William watches them bonding over the oddest thing - his failure. William goes into the bedroom, the final three feet to sleep, and shuts the door.  A hand places a hotel sign on the door -
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (so worried) What are we going to do about him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.  Whatever happened to him, I just wish it could have happened to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The magazine killed his story.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .  Slight push in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He collapses with all his clothes on, almost instantly asleep.  His walls, just as he left them, boast a pantheon of rock heroes... with a very lonely Abraham Lincoln (or Atticus Finch)  in the center.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ROLLING STONE OFFICES -- DAY                                        161 The elevator doors ding open, and out walks Russell Hammond. The Secretary has just finished answering the phone, "Straight Arrow Publishers."  She puts the caller on hold.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hi, I'm Russel Hammond.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're here regarding?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . EDITORIAL OFFICE - DAY                                        162 Russell stands with the editors, observing the fine portraits on the walls.  He's behind enemy lines, and he knows it. Everything in the room fascinates him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nearby, David Felton looks at another editor, raising an eyebrow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Russell looks around at the numerous portraits if dead legendary rock stars, fixing on the one photo closest to all of them, a very vulnerable-looking Janis Joplin.  A second thought.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at their faces.  They cannot disagree.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I don't care what happens.  I don't care if you put us on the cover.  But you sent us a kid and... and he was a fan.   And we all made friends with him - absolutely, to get a good story. But then we actually liked him.  We thought he's... show us our lives in some mythic way and I guess... we're not mythic.  We panicked.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You denied most of the story.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, well, here's the problem with the truth.  It's too true -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, we appreciate the visit.  The last time an artist came here, it was Buddy Miles and he punched me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not punching anybody.  I am personally, as of 2 pm yesterday, on a voyage of self-reinvention.  This is about William Miller. (counting off fingers) He lives with us, he lost his virginity, he saw us at our worst, appreciated our best, he saved two lives, including mine... he smuggled about a half-pound of pot into Boston, and we never even told him -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: we told him too much, we told him everything...  He almost died with us over Tupelo... if the band survives him, it'll be a miracle... but you know, he tried to keep up, and that's a journalist to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's too late.  We're going with a different cover.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (immediately) Thank God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) You tell me it's too late.  But I could go back to my hotel room and... and O.D. tonight and something tells me you'd find a way to put me on the cover of the next issue.  Am I right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) I'm learning the game. (beat, shrug) We fucked up.  We made friends with him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Next time we'll all be more professional.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe so. (beat, an odd thought) But God forbid, the day comes when selling yourself is as important as the music you make. (rueful, to Hendrix on the wall) You might have died at the right time, my friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you for visiting.  Good luck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do what you want, but the story is true.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: RUSSELL at the entrance.  Raises his hand.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) Good evening!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . SAN FRANCISCO - DAY                                                162A Russell stands outside, a traveling man with no where to go. Oddly, and in a way that surprises him, the world begins to speak to him again... little noises everywhere, turning into a music of its own.  It's a beautiful and compelling "silence." He thrusts his hands deep in his pockets, and takes a breath of life.  His head filling again with the music of the world, he begins to walk down the street.  Very naturally, and quite randomly, he is noticed by young passersby.  They can't help it.  He looks like a star.  They can't quite figure out who it is, but it's someone, and they begin to follow him down the street.   Unbeknownst to him as he walks along, deep in thought, a small crowd begins to form... following him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BREAKFAST TABLE - DAY                                        163 A quiet kitchen.  Anita has been cooking.  A substantial breakfast has been placed on the table.  Sausage, orange juice... and now Anita sets down a plate of pancakes, with syrup and butter, in front of her mother.  William watches his mother facing an old enemy - white sugar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mom looks at her children, and takes a breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She goes to the stereo and puts on a record.  The two children eye each other - what's coming next?  (Song to be chosen) The two kids eye each other again.  Self-consciously avoiding their gaze, Mom sits and toys with her breakfast.  It's a song she clearly wants them to hear.  It's a song from the heart. They look at her, amazed.  Elaine looks up, regards her family. Somehow they're back at this table.  They continue eating breakfast.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: They're called pancakes.  Who knows when we'll be together again.  Splurge. It's what most people call breakfast.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I went through your records.  And I found a song to play for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Bam.  A bundle of bound Rolling Stone Magazines lands on the newsstand pavement with a thud.  Someone reaches in to cut the cord, as the magazines puff up into view.  It's the new issue, with Russell Hammond on the cover.  The title: Stillwater Runs Deep.  Just another stack of magazines waiting to be places in the racks.
direction.name: direction
